Hi,
Reviewed the cited sections. Seems indirect encodings could be vie=
wed as a type of user-defined application-specific module. Examples of modu=
le sets abound. Alphabet, Vocabulary, standardized bolts, data compression =
transfer functions... The point being, that the utility of module (or conce=
pt) sets, is a reduction in generic task complexity/construction plan size,=
 etc. The comfort of the "universal approximator" characteristic, is no mor=
e a rational for evolutionary development from scratch using exclusively NN=
 formative elements, than attempting to assemble a car starting from the mo=
lecular level, rather than being constrained to the utilization of standard=
ized parts & bolts. Being constrained to a fixed set of modules/concepts, m=
ay not enable total global optimization, but often times, "close-enough" is=
 just that, close enough. Getting close enough: optimizing based upon a fix=
ed size set of modules/concepts, and then tailoring w/ NN formative element=
s. If the vocabulary shows itself to be too limiting, add as justifiably re=
quired. But regardless of the process of how you identify the module/concep=
t, those modules/concepts MUST be held inviolate within the genome, and thu=
s not contribute to the dimensional operator disruption. Otherwise they are=
 no longer modules/concepts, but rather effectively only "suggestions". And=
 their utility is lost or diminished as a consequence of their contribution=
 to the overall dimensional operator disruption. In other words, the genome=
 needs to have the ability to be partitioned into operator and non-operator=
 regions. The non-operator regions corresponding to the module/concept inte=
rior functionality, and the operator region corresponding to everything els=
e within the genome. Practically speaking, this requires at a minimum, node=
s with uniquely addressable variable number inputs and outputs, with the at=
tendant infrastructure to handle same. Once the utility of using a given bo=
lt has been justified, you don't keep evolving the bolt! You shoot the "bol=
t engineer", and move on with the balance of the task at hand :)

Andy

---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
=
> =C2=A0Agree, BlindBuilder is a nice case of "compact encoding does not me=
ans good encoding", for the reasons you mentionned. Modules are the way to =
go, *BUT*... Most of time, when we say modules, it's some part of the genot=
ype which is taken and grafted somewhere else, verbatim. This is the level =
0 of modularity, it makes tons of assumptions. Assumption that your problem=
 is nice enough to be trivially decomposible into subproblems solveable by =
subpart of genotypes. Assumption that your problem is nice enough to pave t=
he road for you, miraculy making the right modules to appear in the right o=
rder. Yes, with an optimization which is mostly a a biased random walk... I=
 can go on long of that, but, well, let's remove that dust on my PhD thesis=
 and link it here (http://www.marmakoide.org/download/publications/adevert-=
phd-thesis.pdf), and invite you to read from page 21, section 1.3.3, to the=
 end of Chapter 1, which is a good summary of my views on modularity, with
=
>  of course credit for my PhD advisors, Vishnu bless them ^^
>

oups.com

at] Musings On Lessons Learned From BlindBuilder Applied To NEAT & Indirect=
 Encoding
>  
> 
> =C2=A0 
> Alex,
> Your prior work associated w/ BlindBui=
lder I believe is informative and applicable to possible updates to NEAT an=
d indirect encodings in general. The growing disruptive impact of construct=
ion operators as the size of the construction plan increases, seemly underc=
uts the benefit of compact nature of the approach, and also illustrates a f=
undamental strength and weakness of NEAT. NEAT, starting from minimal size,=
 mitigates the disruptive nature of various operators at the beginning allo=
wing for more effective use of computational resources for growing of the o=
rganism in a profitable portion of the design space. But as organism size i=
ncreases, the growing disruptive impact of some operators, and where they a=
re applied, increasingly bog down further progress.
> In the context of Bli=
ndBuilder, two examples are useful:
> 1) Bridge: The concept of a bridge is=
 simple and straight forward. From a construction perspective, could be ach=
ieved with a single element of appropriate size and orientation. While the =
size of the construction plan is vastly different based upon the characteri=
stics of the formative elements, though the concept is still simple, the di=
sruptive impact of various operators on form, fit, function and convergence=
 is also vastly different.
> 2) Wall: Also, the concept of a wall is simple=
 and straight forward. And again from a construction perspective, could be =
achieved with a single element of appropriate size and orientation. The sam=
e comments also apply regarding construction plan size and associated disru=
ptive impact of construction operators.
> The point being, that the sensiti=
vity of the concept should not be subject to the scale of the formative ele=
ments, but rather the suitability of the formulation to the objectives of t=
he concept. In the construction context, this is more straight forward. The=
 overall objective is composed of a relatively few well known concepts take=
n together in some relative orientations WRT each other (i.e. a house can b=
e composed of four orthogonal walls and a roof). The construction operators=
 should be confined to refinement of suitability of the formative elements =
and their orientations taken together WRT the individual concept, guided by=
 concept specific operator selection criteria (i.e. semi-separable multi-su=
bobjectives).
> Of course, in the general case, the identification of conce=
pts is not as straight forward. But efforts to identify reusable genetic ma=
terial snippets would most likely qualify as identification of concepts, an=
d would thus likely benefit from: a) partitioning of the genome for applica=
tion of operators, and b) application of concept specific operator selectio=
n WRT concept suitability for the current overall objective.
> 
> Andy
>
